recipe_xml:
<recipe>
  <title>Smothered Pork Chops with Mushrooms</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['2 pounds bone-in pork shoulder chops'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup all-purpose flour'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons vegetable oil</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large onion</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved and sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 pound fresh cremini mushrooms</ingredient>
    <ingredient>sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon chopped rosemary'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup water']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Pat chops dry and season with 1 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper, then dredge in flour, shaking off excess. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a 12-inch heavy skillet (preferably deep) over medium-high heat until it shimmers. Brown chops in 2 batches, turning once, 3 to 4 minutes total per batch. Transfer to a plate.</step>
    <step>2. Add remaining 2 tablespoon oil to skillet and cook onion and mushrooms with rosemary and 1/4 teaspoon each of salt and pepper over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until browned, about 7 minutes. Return chops and any meat juices from plate to skillet. Add water and simmer, covered, until chops are tender, about 30 minutes.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Singaporean Chili Crab</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['3 cups Super-Concentrated Cantonese Chicken Stock</ingredient>
    <ingredient>hot'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>"1 cup Hunt's brand ketchup"</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 tablespoons lee Kum Kee brand chili garlic sauce'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 tablespoons rice vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 tablespoons sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 fresh Dungeness crab</ingredient>
    <ingredient>or equally large and meaty crab'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup cornstarch'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons minced garlic'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons minced shallots'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon minced ginger'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 Thai chile peppers</ingredient>
    <ingredient>chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 stalk scallion</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut diagonally'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 cups Chili Crab Sauce'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 large eggs'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Scallions</ingredient>
    <ingredient>for garnish</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut diagonally'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Cilantro sprigs</ingredient>
    <ingredient>for garnish'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 Buttermilk Beer Beignets']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing bowl (or 22-quart plastic Cambro containers, like we do) until it becomes one unified homogenous mixture of red chili sauce. It should taste spicy, sweet, and savory and not too ketchup-y.</step>
    <step>2. Clean crab and cut into pieces. If you have never done this before, this might sound easier said than done, but it's not nearly as daunting as it seems.</step>
    <step>3. In a debate of “humane” ways of killing crab: the Asian preparation of crab is a near-instant killing of the crab versus the longer and drawn out steaming/boiling method. Additionally, the boiling method tends to result in a much fishier “crabby” flavor, not as fresh tasting as with this method. If you look up videos on YouTube, look up “How to kill a live crab humanely,” which will demonstrate this way of breaking down a crab.</step>
    <step>4. With that said, I wasn’t as prepared in the photograph process, so I’m going to personally walk you through this as the first “Crab Killer” at Starry Kitchen:</step>
    <step>5. Quick tips: Put crabs in the freezer or refrigerator before breaking down. It will make them sleepy—slow them down very severely. There is also a way one of our cooks, Sean, uncovered on the web to gently pet a soft spot on their shell over and over and they’ll start falling asleep. We’ve seen it. It’s crazy, but it takes a lot longer than the freezer method.</step>
    <step>6. Next, when you’re ready, you’re going to need a decently sharp knife for this process or at least one with a sharp tip for this next step: try to grab the crab from the tail end, and flip the crab over, claws and eyes pointing away from you, and so it’s belly-side up. If you look at its abdomen right in the center, you’ll see a longer triangular lip (top of it pointing away from you) that can actually be lifted up. Until you’re comfortable doing it often, you can use the tip of your knife to lift it up, but you’ll want to use your hand to quickly just lift up and fold it over completely. The crab will potentially get VERY mad at this point. You’ve just exposed its most vulnerable spot.</step>
    <step>7. Then, this part is simple if you can move quickly: just stab it downward right through that spot that’s been exposed until you reach the shell. Hold for about 10–20 seconds. The crab should die almost instantly.</step>
    <step>8. Afterwards, line your knife across the middle, and firmly press down and cleave it through the abdomen to cut the crab in half. The crab will snap in half once you come all the way down. You’ll also be able to pull the crab by each of its claws, and it’ll just come apart.</step>
    <step>9. You’ll then want to turn each half over, and remove the white gills off of each and dispose.</step>
    <step>10. Dispose of the lip, and any other loose appendages from the front and back end of the crab.</step>
    <step>11. Dispose of the white film and any black matter inside the shell itself, but do not clean out the rest of the shell. That orange part, the coral, the fatty tissue is the MOST coveted part of the crab in Asian households (typically held for the father, no joke). It’s like sea urchin/uni, really rich and very briny...and super-awesome to put rice into once it’s cooked and scoop it out with. Yummers!</step>
    <step>12. Depending on how large your crab is, the two halves of crab legs can be broken into either 2 or 3 sections (there should be a minimum of 2 legs per section) using the same cleaving action as you did to halve the crab.</step>
    <step>13. And that’s it! (If YouTube, this, and the web doesn’t help you feel more comfortable—seriously, feel free to reach out to us: @starrykitchen. This dish is COMPLETELY worth it.)</step>
    <step>14. Now clean the crab legs again, then pat dry with paper towels. Put into a big bowl with cornstarch, but make sure to leave enough room to coat crab with starch.</step>
    <step>15. Diligently dredge all exposed crab pieces including the coral and head, inside and out, with starch. Next, shake off excess starch, but make sure all of the exposed (non-shelled) parts are covered in starch. This seals in all of the crab’s flavors throughout the cooking process. This is especially important if you need to prepare in advance.</step>
    <step>16. Fill a wok/pot with 2 to 3 inches cooking oil, enough to submerge crab pieces, including the head. Heat oil to 350°F over high heat, then carefully fry in batches, arranging crab pieces in a single layer in the oil. Turn over pieces with tongs to fry evenly.</step>
    <step>17. When the crab pieces turn red all over and the battered parts are golden, remove and shake the excess oil over your pot. Set aside (we like to set crab on a rack/grate and baking sheet to allow a little bit more oil to drip off). Refrigerate for up to 24 hours.</step>
    <step>18. Once you’re ready to make your chili crab, heat a wok/pan on high heat and add 1 tablespoon cooking oil per crab. Sauté garlic, shallots, ginger, and chiles until aromatic (enough to make you cough—that’s how you know you got the GOOD stuff). Next, add the beautiful monstrosity that is your crab. Stir quickly for 10 to 15 seconds, then add Chili Crab Sauce. Cover, cook over high heat, and cook that bad boy (or girl) for 7 minutes.</step>
    <step>19. Keep the pan over heat, but remove crab from pan and place on a serving dish. While reconstructing your sea beast, make sure to leave all the sauce in the wok/pan. Crack eggs into the sauce, and quickly mix to fully incorporate them and thicken the sauce. Increase to high heat and reduce sauce to desired thickness. (I like it pretty thick and a little bit gloppy GOOD.) Once done, remove from heat, and pour sauce all over the crab. Garnish with chopped scallions and cilantro. Serve with Buttermilk Beer Beignets. Break down the crab, sop up all that sauce, and eat like a Singaporean king!</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Peppermint Cosmo</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 cup pomegranate juice'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Juice of 1 lime'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 ounces vodka'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon peppermint extract'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'8 ice cubes'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'8 mini candy canes'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons chopped fresh mint']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Combine juices, vodka, peppermint and 1/2 cup water in a shaker with ice. Shake vigorously and strain into 8 shot glasses. Garnish with candy canes and mint.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Southwestern-Style Baby Back Ribs</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 tablespoon dried thyme'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon granulated garlic'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon onion powder'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon brown sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon paprika'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon chili powder'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon dried rosemary'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon ground black pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 racks baby back ribs</ingredient>
    <ingredient>about 5 pounds'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 cups barbecue sauce']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. In a small bowl, mix together the thyme, garlic, onion powder, brown sugar, paprika, chili powder, rosemary, salt, and black pepper. Rub the spice mixture over both sides of the ribs. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate overnight or up to 24 hours.</step>
    <step>2. Preheat the oven to 325°F. Unwrap the ribs and place them on a baking sheet. Cover completely with foil. Bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes. Remove the foil and let the ribs cool. Refrigerate them, wrapped in plastic, until you are ready to pack, up to 24 hours.</step>
    <step>3. Just before leaving, cut the racks into individual ribs and place them in a large, sealable plastic container. Add 1 cup of the barbecue sauce and stir so all the ribs are coated.</step>
    <step>4. Prepare coals for a medium fire. When the coals are hot, grill the ribs for 10 minutes, until they are lightly charred and heated through, turning them several times and applying several more moppings of sauce.</step>
    <step>5. Serve the ribs hot, accompanied by more sauce.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Spicy Lamb Meatballs with Raisin Pesto</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 large egg'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup panko (Japanese breadcrumbs)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 tsp ground cumin'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 tsp ground turmeric'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup finely chopped parsley</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus 1 cup parsley leaves with tender stems'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tbsp plus 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 tsp kosher salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 lb. ground lamb'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 cups mint leaves'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tbsp golden raisins'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Plain whole-milk greek yogurt (for serving)']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place a rack in upper third of oven</step>
    <step>2. preheat to 425°F. Combine egg, panko, cumin, red pepper flakes, turmeric, finely chopped parsley, 2 Tbsp. oil, and 1 1/2 tsp. salt in a large bowl. Finely grate 1 garlic clove into bowl. Add lamb and mix with your hands until evenly distributed.</step>
    <step>3. Gently roll lamb mixture into 1 1/2"-diameter balls (about the size of a golf ball</step>
    <step>4. you should have about 20). Place on a rimmed baking sheet, spacing evenly apart. Bake meatballs until browned and cooked through, 8–10 minutes.</step>
    <step>5. Meanwhile, purée mint, raisins, parsley leaves with tender stems, remaining garlic clove, remaining 1/2 cup oil, and a big pinch of salt in a blender until smooth. Taste pesto</step>
    <step>6. season with more salt if needed.</step>
    <step>7. Spread yogurt over plates and divide pesto and meatballs on top.</step>
    <step>8. Pesto can be made 2 days ahead</step>
    <step>9. cover and chill. Meatballs can be formed 2 months ahead</step>
    <step>10. freeze on baking sheet until firm, about 2 hours, then transfer to a freezer bag and keep frozen.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Wild Rice with Butternut Squash, Leeks, and Corn</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 1/2 cups wild rice (about 9 ounces)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 teaspoons coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 cups 1/2-inch cubes peeled butternut squash (from 11/2-pound squash)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 tablespoons (3/4 stick) butter</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 cups finely chopped leeks (white part only)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 cups frozen white corn kernels</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thawed'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon chopped fresh Italian parsley']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Rinse rice in strainer under cold water</step>
    <step>2. drain. Bring 6 cups water and 2 teaspoons coarse salt to boil in large saucepan. Add rice</step>
    <step>3. bring to boil. Reduce heat</step>
    <step>4. simmer uncovered until rice grains begin to split and are tender but still slightly chewy, about 45 minutes. Drain. Spread on rimmed baking sheet to cool. Transfer to bowl. DO AHEAD: Can be made 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
    <step>5. Preheat oven to 350°F. Oil rimmed baking sheet. Toss squash cubes and 3 tablespoons oil in medium bowl. Spread squash in single layer on prepared sheet</step>
    <step>6. sprinkle with salt and pepper. Roast just until tender but firm enough to hold shape, stirring occasionally, about 15 minutes. Transfer squash to bowl. Cool. DO AHEAD: Can be made 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
    <step>7. Melt 4 tablespoons butter in large skillet over medium heat. Add leeks and 3/4 cup water</step>
    <step>8. simmer until leeks are tender, about 7 minutes. Add corn</step>
    <step>9. simmer 2 minutes longer. Add rice and butternut squash</step>
    <step>10. simmer until heated through and liquid is absorbed, about 4 minutes. Stir in 2 tablespoons butter and parsley. Season with salt and pepper. Transfer to bowl and serve.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Crispy Shaken Potatoes With Rosemary</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['8 large russet potatoes (about 4 pounds)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup canola oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons fresh rosemary leaves'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon kosher salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more for seasoning']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Preheat the oven to 425°F.</step>
    <step>2. Cut the potatoes into 1-inch chunks. Place in a large stockpot, cover in cold water and add a teaspoon of kosher salt. Set over high heat, cover, and bring to a boil. Lower the heat to medium and simmer for 15 to 20 minutes or until fork tender but still firm in the center.</step>
    <step>3. Drain the potatoes in a colander, then place them back in the empty stockpot. Cover with a lid and shake the pot vigorously for a few seconds, until the surface of the potato is fuzzy</step>
    <step>4. this will help the formation of a crust. Season potatoes generously with salt.</step>
    <step>5. Add the oil to a 13x18 inch sheet or roasting pan and place in the oven until oil is hot and almost smoking, about 5 minutes. Remove the roasting pan and carefully add the potatoes. Return pan to oven and roast for 30 minutes. Flip the potatoes, scatter with rosemary, and continue to cook until the potatoes are crispy and brown, 10 to 15 minutes more.</step>
    <step>6. Return potatoes to the oven to rewarm at 350°F for 10 minutes before serving.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Cherry, Pistachio & Coconut Cake</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1/2 cup/100g sugar</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus 1 1/2 tbsp/20g for the topping'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup/90g light brown sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/4 cup/180g ground almonds'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup/30g ground pistachios'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup/45g desiccated coconut'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/3 cup plus 1 tbsp/50g self-rising flour (preferably gold Medal brand)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'A pinch of salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/4 tsp ground mahleb'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'10 tbsp/150g butter</ingredient>
    <ingredient>melted'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 large eggs'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 cups/300g cherries'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Scant 1/2 cup/50g roughly chopped pistachios</ingredient>
    <ingredient>for the topping']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Preheat the oven to 375°F and lightly grease a 9 in/24cm diameter ring cake tin with butter.</step>
    <step>2. Mix all the dry ingredients together in a large bowl. Pour over the melted butter and mix in the eggs. Spoon the batter into the pre-greased tin and smooth down.</step>
    <step>3. Remove the pits from the cherries—you can do this with a cherry pitter or by just pulling them apart and popping the pits out with your fingers. I like to do this over the cake tin, so that any juice drips onto the cake and adds color. Drop the pitted cherries onto the batter and sprinkle the top of the cake with the remaining 1 1/2 tbsp/20g of sugar and the roughly chopped pistachios. Bake in the center of the oven for 25–30 minutes, then turn the cake around and bake for a further 8–10 minutes, until the cake between the cherries goes all golden.</step>
    <step>4. Allow the cake to cool in the tin, as it needs time to settle, then gently remove by running a knife around the edges. Covered well, it will keep in the fridge for up to a week (not much chance of that happening), but for the best flavor, allow it to return to room temperature before eating.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Mustard Greens with Chipotle and Bacon</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['2 3/4 pounds curly mustard greens (2 to 3 bunches)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>stems and coarse ribs discarded'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 bacon slices</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut crosswise into 1/2-inch pieces'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon minced canned chipotle chiles in adobo'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon salt']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Coarsely chop greens, then cook in 2 batches in a 6- to 8-quart pot of boiling salted water , uncovered, stirring occasionally, until wilted and tender, about 5 minutes. Transfer with a slotted spoon to a large bowl of cold water to stop cooking. Drain greens in a colander, pressing gently to release excess moisture.</step>
    <step>2. Cook bacon in a 12-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat, stirring, until crisp, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer with a slotted spoon to paper towels to drain, reserving fat in skillet. Add oil, chipotle, greens, and salt to fat and cook, stirring occasionally, until heated through, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer to a serving dish and sprinkle with bacon.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Cucumber, Mustard, and Dill Salad</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['2 teaspoons white-wine vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 teaspoons Dijon mustard'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>or to taste'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon mild olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large seedless cucumber (usually plastic-wrapped; 1 lb)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons chopped fresh dill']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Whisk together vinegar, mustard, salt, and sugar in a bowl, then add oil in a slow stream, whisking.</step>
    <step>2. Halve cucumber lengthwise and remove seeds with a small spoon, then cut halves crosswise into 1/8-inch-thick slices.</step>
    <step>3. Add cucumber and dill to vinaigrette, tossing to coat.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Fig and Onion Bruschetta</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1/2 cup dried black Mission figs</ingredient>
    <ingredient>stemmed</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup boiling water'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup dry red wine'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 small bay leaf'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/8 teaspoon coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon red wine vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons butter'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons extra-virgin olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 medium red onion</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved through core</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut lengthwise into 1/2-inch-thick strips'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons red wine vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup fresh ricotta cheese'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil plus additional for drizzling'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon heavy whipping cream'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'8 1-inch-thick slices ciabatta bread (about 4 1/2 x 2 inches)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons chopped fresh oregano']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place figs in small bowl. Pour 1 cup boiling water over</step>
    <step>2. let soak 45 minutes. Drain figs</step>
    <step>3. place in small saucepan. Add wine and next 3 ingredients</step>
    <step>4. bring to boil, stirring to dissolve sugar. Reduce heat to medium. Simmer until figs are tender and liquid is syrupy, stirring occasionally, about 20 minutes. Add vinegar</step>
    <step>5. cook 1 minute longer. Remove pan from heat</step>
    <step>6. cool.</step>
    <step>7. Melt butter with oil in medium skillet over medium-high heat. Add onion</step>
    <step>8. sauté until beginning to soften and brown, stirring occasionally, about 4 minutes. Reduce heat to low</step>
    <step>9. add vinegar and sugar, then sprinkle with coarse salt and pepper. Stir until vinegar has almost evaporated, about 1 minute. Cool. DO AHEAD: Figs and onion mixture can be made 2 hours ahead. Let stand at room temperature.</step>
    <step>10. Whisk ricotta, 1 tablespoon oil, and cream in medium bowl until fluffy. Season with coarse salt and pepper. Preheat broiler. Drizzle ciabatta with some olive oil and sprinkle with coarse salt and pepper. Broil bread on both sides until toasted. Transfer to serving plate. Spread 2 tablespoons ricotta mixture on each bread slice. Spoon glazed figs with some of syrup over</step>
    <step>11. top with onion mixture. Sprinkle with Parmesan and oregano. Drizzle with oil and serve immediately.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Stuffed Chicken Breasts with Rosemary-Orange Dressing</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 cup pitted brine-cured green olives'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large garlic clove</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons chopped fresh rosemary'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon finely grated orange peel'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 boneless chicken breast halves with skin'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 tablespoons orange juice'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons chopped fresh rosemary'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>pressed'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon finely grated orange peel'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup chopped pitted brine-cured green olives'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Nonstick vegetable oil spray'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 large unpeeled oranges</ingredient>
    <ingredient>each cut into 6 wedges']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Blend first 5 ingredients in mini processor until olives and garlic are chopped. Transfer stuffing to small bowl</step>
    <step>2. season with salt and pepper. Using fingertips, gently loosen skin on 1 chicken breast, leaving 1 long side attached. Spread 1/6 of stuffing over flesh under skin. Pull skin flap over to cover</step>
    <step>3. secure flap with metal pin or toothpick. Repeat with remaining chicken and stuffing. Arrange chicken on large rimmed baking sheet. DO AHEAD: Can be made 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
    <step>4. Combine first 4 ingredients in medium bowl. Gradually whisk in oil, then olives. Season dressing to taste with salt and pepper. Transfer 3/4 cup dressing to small bowl</step>
    <step>5. reserve for serving.</step>
    <step>6. Coat grill rack with nonstick spray and prepare barbecue (medium-high heat). Divide remaining dressing between 2 small cups. Drizzle chicken with dressing from 1 cup. Arrange orange wedges on sheet of foil</step>
    <step>7. brush oranges with dressing from second cup.</step>
    <step>8. Grill chicken until cooked through, drizzling with dressing from first cup and turning occasionally, 12 to 14 minutes. Grill orange wedges until heated through and slightly charred, turning and brushing often with dressing from second cup, about 10 minutes. Transfer chicken and orange wedges to platter. Serve with reserved 3/4 cup dressing.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Blueberry Lemon Cream Tarts</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 cup graham cracker crumbs'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 tablespoons granulated sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 stick (4 tablespoons) unsalted butter</ingredient>
    <ingredient>melted'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons packed light brown sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup sour cream'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon vanilla'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'4 oz cream cheese</ingredient>
    <ingredient>softened'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon finely grated fresh lemon zest'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/3 cups blueberries (6 ounces)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Confectioners sugar for dusting'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Special equipment: 4 (3 3/4-inch) nonstick fluted tart pans or 4 (8-ounces) ramekins']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Preheat oven to 350°F with a baking sheet on middle rack.</step>
    <step>2. Stir together graham cracker crumbs, granulated sugar, and butter in a bowl with a fork until combined well, then press mixture with your fingers and back of a spoon evenly and firmly onto bottom and up side of each tart pan. (If using ramekins, press mixture 3/4 inch up sides.)</step>
    <step>3. Put tart pans on preheated baking sheet and bake crusts until slightly darker, about 10 minutes, then cool 10 minutes on a rack. (Ramekins will need to cool an additional 5 minutes in refrigerator.) Gently push bottom of each tart pan to loosen crust, then invert crust onto your hand and place on a serving plate. (If using ramekins, leave crusts in ramekins.)</step>
    <step>4. While crusts cool, whisk together brown sugar, sour cream, and vanilla in a small bowl until sugar is dissolved. Beat cream cheese in a medium bowl with an electric mixer until smooth, then add sour cream mixture and zest, beating until just combined well.</step>
    <step>5. Divide cream cheese filling among tart shells, spreading evenly, then top with blueberries and dust with confectioners sugar.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Grapefruit Marmalade with Vanilla and Anise</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 3/4-pound ruby red grapefruit (about 2)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 star anise pods'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 vanilla bean</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved lengthwise'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 cups sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup fresh lemon juice']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Using a sharp knife, remove peel and white pith from 1 grapefruit and thinly slice. Remove peel and white pith from remaining grapefruit and discard (you won’t want all of the peel and pith in the marmalade). Slice flesh of both grapefruits into rounds</step>
    <step>2. remove any seeds.</step>
    <step>3. Combine sliced peel, grapefruit, and star anise in a large saucepan</step>
    <step>4. scrape in seeds from vanilla bean and add pod. Toss to combine</step>
    <step>5. pour in 4 cups water and bring mixture to a boil. Reduce heat and gently simmer until reduced by three-quarters, about 1 1/2 hours. Add sugar, return to a simmer, and cook until mixture is thickened and juices are syrupy (mixture will set up when a small amount is spooned onto a cold plate), 1–1 1/2 hours longer.</step>
    <step>6. Let marmalade cool slightly, then stir in lemon juice. Spoon into clean jars and let cool.</step>
    <step>7. Marmalade can be made 2 months ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Spanakopita</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 stick (1/2 cup) plus 1 tablespoon unsalted butter'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 lb baby spinach'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 lb feta</ingredient>
    <ingredient>crumbled (scant 2 cups)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'10 (17- by 12-inch) phyllo sheets</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thawed if frozen']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Melt 1 tablespoon butter in a 12-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat, then cook spinach, stirring, until wilted and tender, about 4 minutes. Remove from heat and cool, about 10 minutes. Squeeze handfuls of spinach to remove as much liquid as possible, then coarsely chop. Transfer to a bowl and stir in feta, nutmeg, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper.</step>
    <step>2. Preheat oven to 375°F.</step>
    <step>3. Melt remaining 1 stick butter in a small saucepan, then cool.</step>
    <step>4. Cover phyllo stack with 2 overlapping sheets of plastic wrap and then a dampened kitchen towel.</step>
    <step>5. Take 1 phyllo sheet from stack and arrange on a work surface with a long side nearest you (keeping remaining sheets covered) and brush with some butter. Top with another phyllo sheet and brush with more butter. Cut buttered phyllo stack crosswise into 6 (roughly 12- by 2 3/4-inch) strips.</step>
    <step>6. Put a heaping teaspoon of filling near 1 corner of a strip on end nearest you, then fold corner of phyllo over to enclose filling and form a triangle. Continue folding strip (like a flag), maintaining triangle shape. Put triangle, seam side down, on a large baking sheet and brush top with butter. Make more triangles in same manner, using all of phyllo.</step>
    <step>7. Bake triangles in middle of oven until golden brown, 20 to 25 minutes, then transfer to a rack to cool slightly.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Char-Grilled Beef Tenderloin with Three-Herb Chimichurri</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['2 tablespoons dark brown sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon sweet smoked paprika*'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon coarse kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 teaspoons chipotle chile powder or ancho chile powder'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon ground black pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons Sherry wine vinegar or red wine vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 medium shallots</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled</ingredient>
    <ingredient>quartered'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon fine sea salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 teaspoon dried crushed red pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 cups (packed) stemmed fresh parsley'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 cups (packed) stemmed fresh cilantro'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup (packed) stemmed fresh mint'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 3 1/2-pound beef tenderloin'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons olive oil']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Combine all ingredients in small bowl.</step>
    <step>2. Do ahead: Can be made 2 days ahead. Store airtight at room temperature.</step>
    <step>3. Combine first 8 ingredients in blender</step>
    <step>4. blend until almost smooth. Add 1/4 of parsley, 1/4 of cilantro, and 1/4 of mint</step>
    <step>5. blend until incorporated. Add remaining herbs in 3 more additions, pureeing until almost smooth after each addition.</step>
    <step>6. Do ahead: Can be made 3 hours ahead. Cover</step>
    <step>7. chill.</step>
    <step>8. Let beef stand at room temperature 1 hour.</step>
    <step>9. Prepare barbecue (high heat). Pat beef dry with paper towels</step>
    <step>10. brush with oil. Sprinkle all over with spice rub, using all of mixture (coating will be thick). Place beef on grill</step>
    <step>11. sear 2 minutes on each side. Reduce heat to medium-high. Grill uncovered until instant-read thermometer inserted into thickest part of beef registers 130°F for medium-rare, moving beef to cooler part of grill as needed to prevent burning, and turning occasionally, about 40 minutes. Transfer to platter</step>
    <step>12. cover loosely with foil and let rest 15 minutes. Thinly slice beef crosswise. Serve with chimichurri sauce.</step>
    <step>13. *Available at specialty foods stores and from tienda.com.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Chipotle-Style Cilantro-Lime Rice</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 cup white jasmine rice'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon kosher salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons finely chopped cilantro'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons unsalted butter'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon fresh lime juice']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Rinse rice several times with cold water until water runs clear. Drain well in a fine-mesh sieve. Transfer rice to a medium pot. Add salt and 1 1/4 cups water, cover, and bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce heat to low and cook, covered, until rice is tender and liquid is absorbed, 18–21 minutes.</step>
    <step>2. Remove from heat. Let stand, covered and undisturbed, 10 minutes. Use a fork to fluff, then gently fold in cilantro, butter, and lime juice.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Parmesan Broth</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 halved head of garlic'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 quartered onion'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'olive oil</ingredient>
    <ingredient>enough to sauté garlic and onion'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 handful of thyme'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Sprigs of parsley'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 bay leaf'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 shake of black peppercorns'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup of dry white wine'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 pound Parmesan rinds'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'8 cups of water']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. I start by sautéing a halved head of garlic and a quartered onion in some olive oil, along with a handful of thyme, a few sprigs of parsley, a bay leaf, and a shake of black peppercorns. Once the garlic is browned, I add a cup of dry white wine and simmer, scraping the pot to get the brown bits loosened up, until reduced by half. In goes 1 pound Parmesan rinds and 8 cups of water.</step>
    <step>2. The whole thing simmers until it tastes robust and has reduced by half, about 2 hours. (I stir every now and then—the rinds will stick to the bottom of the pot if you let them.) I strain, and then use the broth in vegetable soups, instant-supper pastas, and beans in need of a boost. Then I start hoarding all over again.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>James Beard's Roasted Spareribs</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['4 pounds meaty pork spareribs'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Preheat oven to 350°F.</step>
    <step>2. Rub the ribs with salt and pepper on both sides.</step>
    <step>3. Set a roasting or broiler rack in a roasting pan. Arrange the ribs on the rack, meaty side facing up.</step>
    <step>4. Put the pan on the center rack of the oven and bake for 30 minutes. Using a pair of tongs, turn the ribs over, and cook for another 30 minutes.</step>
    <step>5. When the second 30 minutes are up, the ribs should be nicely browned and fairly crisp on the outside. If not, roast for another 10 minutes and check again.</step>
    <step>6. When you are serving the ribs, cut the rack into separate racks of 3 or 4 ribs per person and place on a platter or plates. Serve hot.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Spicy Black Bean and Corn Tacos</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1/4 cup hazelnuts</ingredient>
    <ingredient>coarsely chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup raw pumpkin seeds'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 ears of corn</ingredient>
    <ingredient>shucked'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 medium jalapeño</ingredient>
    <ingredient>seeded</ingredient>
    <ingredient>finely chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup chopped cilantro</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus more for serving'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 tablespoons olive oil</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 tablespoons fresh lime juice</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided</ingredient>
    <ingredient>plus lime wedges for serving'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/4 teaspoons kosher salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 red onion</ingredient>
    <ingredient>coarsely chopped'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 (15-ounce) cans black beans</ingredient>
    <ingredient>rinsed</ingredient>
    <ingredient>drained'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon ground cumin'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'12 small corn tortillas'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup sour cream'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large avocado</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Toast hazelnuts and pumpkin seeds in a medium skillet over medium heat, tossing occasionally, until golden brown, 8–10 minutes.</step>
    <step>2. Meanwhile, slice corn off cobs into a large bowl (you should have about 2 cups kernels). Add toasted nuts and seeds, jalapeño, red pepper, 1/4 cup chopped cilantro, 1/4 cup oil, 3 Tbsp. lime juice, and 1/2 tsp. salt</step>
    <step>3. toss to combine.</step>
    <step>4. Heat remaining 1 Tbsp. oil in a medium skillet over medium. Add onion and cook, stirring, until onion starts to release moisture and turns translucent, 4–5 minutes. Add beans, cumin, 1/3 cup water, and remaining 3/4 tsp. salt. Cover and cook until liquid is reduced and beans soften, about 5 minutes. Uncover, add 1/3 cup water, and use the back of a fork to mash up about half of beans.</step>
    <step>5. Working one at a time, warm tortillas with tongs directly over a gas burner over medium heat, turning often, until lightly charred and puffed in spots, about 45 seconds per side. (Alternatively, wrap tortillas in foil and heat in a 350°F oven until warmed through, or wrap in damp paper towels and microwave in 20-second bursts until warm.) Transfer to a plate and cover with a kitchen towel to keep warm.</step>
    <step>6. Whisk sour cream and remaining 2 Tbsp. lime juice in a small bowl. Fill tortillas with bean mixture, then top with corn salsa, avocado, and cilantro leaves. Drizzle with sour cream mixture and serve with lime wedges alongside.</step>
    <step>7. Corn salsa and beans can be made 3 days ahead</step>
    <step>8. store separately, cover, and chill. Bring corn salsa to room temperature. Reheat beans in skillet before serving.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>
